Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 10/29/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the
institution shall complete a written evaluation of the
convictions that addresses the nature of the conviction,
the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity for

the purpose of determining suitability for employment in
the institution.
One of twenty-nine new employee files did not have a written statement from the
agency assessing the employee's criminal history, prior to employment.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
One of twenty-nine new employee files did not have a written statement from the
employee regarding their criminal history, prior to employment.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Employee evaluations- If an employee evaluation cannot be completed timely,
the agency must document the reason for the delay in the employee file, then
complete the evaluation when able.
• Employee education verification- One employee file held a screen shot of a
college transcript which was difficult to read. The agency was advised to make
sure any copies are clear before placing them in the file.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Team Leader position clarification- the agency was informed that a team
leader is not considered a supervisor under licensing rules, unless the team
leader supervises and evaluates staff. A team leader can be the lead direct
care worker on shift.
• Behavior Management- The agency reported the plan to switch from Crisis
Prevention Institute training to Safety Care as their behavior management
model in 2025. The agency was provided the required form to submit to DCWL
to approve the use of Safety Care.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted four acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• Interim evaluation dated 1/3/24, CAP approved 1/25/24. Two violations
were found regarding timely school enrollment and timely treatment plans.
As of this review, there were no repeat violations. The agency has
implemented and successfully followed their CAP.
• Special Evaluation 2024C0001011SI dated 2/27/24, CAP approved
3/19/24. The agency was cited due to a staff member failing to correctly
report suspected abuse or neglect. The agency implemented their CAP and
has not had any repeat violations.
• Special Evaluation 2024SOC0001371 dated 5/17/24, CAP approved
10/21/24. Violations were found regarding derogatory language toward
youth, staff not following one-to-one supervision, and staff not following
agency policy. The agency implemented their CAP in June 2024 and the
CAP continues to be monitored by DCWL at this time.
• Special Evaluation 2024SIC0001471 dated 7/22/24, CAP approved
10/15/24. Violations were found due to staff failing to follow the agency
policy regarding boundaries with youth. The agency implemented their CAP
in August 2024 and the CAP continues to be monitored by DCWL at this
time.
Financial Overview
The agency’s 12/1/2023 financial statement and 2024 budget were reviewed. No
financial concerns were noted.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment dated 10/24/24 was reviewed and discussed.
The assessment indicated the agency was able to successfully implement the
CAP from the 1/3/24 Interim Review. The agency did not face any barriers during
CAP implementation. Additional CAPs that were the result of special evaluations,
were also implemented and included steps such as staff training, termination,
performance reviews, staffing reassignments, policy review and discussion. Chief
Administrator reported ongoing monthly monitoring and management review of all
CAPs.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. Overall, staff reported that they enjoyed
working with the youth and felt supported by the agency. Staff indicated they
struggled with youth behaviors at times, but felt they had sufficient training and
support from supervisors. However, staff reported feeling overwhelmed with
mandated overtime and extra shifts, due to being short staffed. Some staff felt that
new employees were not well prepared for what the job entailed. Staff also
reported feeling that they needed more ‘real time’ information on youth to better
assist them when they start their shift.

Three youth were interviewed on-site. Overall, youth stated that they felt safe and
supported by staff. Youth indicated they receive enough food, hygiene supplies,
and felt that the school program was helpful to reach their goals. However, youth
also stated they did not feel there was a good reward system. This was due to
peers acting out and ruining activities for the whole group, or peers acting out and
still getting rewards. Some youth reported they did not enjoy the food at the facility
and felt that it was not cooked the way they liked it. Youth reported they would like
more independent living skills and outings. Staff often plan things, but peer
behavior disrupts the plans.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was observed and found to be clean and safe. There was some wear
and tear to the buildings, as a result of youth acting out and kicking doors or
picking at walls and trim. The agency has a full-time maintenance staff that
addresses these issues in a timely manner. Youth were found to have adequate
beds and bedding. No concerns were noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
